description:
Represents additional information about a relationship or property. For example a Role can be used to say that a 'member' role linking some SportsTeam to a player occurred during a particular time period. Or that a Person's 'actor' role in a Movie was for some particular characterName. Such properties can be attached to a Role entity, which is then associated with the main entities using ordinary properties like 'member' or 'actor'.

See also blog post.
title: Role

startDate.description: The start date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

endDate.description: The end date and time of the item (in ISO 8601 date format).

description.description: A short description of the item.

sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

namedPosition.description: A position played, performed or filled by a person or organization, as part of an organization. For example, an athlete in a SportsTeam might play in the position named 'Quarterback'.

additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

mainEntityOfPage.description:
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.

See background notes for details.

roleName.description: A role played, performed or filled by a person or organization. For example, the team of creators for a comic book might fill the roles named 'inker', 'penciller', and 'letterer'; or an athlete in a SportsTeam might play in the position named 'Quarterback'.
